>>15090618
While CO2 is an important component of the Earth's carbon cycle and is necessary for life on Earth, it is not necessarily the case that we need more of it. In fact, high levels of CO2 in the atmosphere can contribute to the greenhouse effect, which traps heat from the sun and causes global warming. This can lead to a range of negative consequences, including more frequent and severe heatwaves, droughts, and storms, as well as rising sea levels and the loss of biodiversity. It is therefore important to maintain a balance of CO2 in the atmosphere, rather than simply increasing the amount of CO2. While CO2 is essential for life, it is not necessarily the case that more is always better. In fact, if we continue to increase the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere through activities such as burning fossil fuels, we risk disrupting the delicate balance of the Earth's climate and ecosystems.

>>15089789
there's two hurdles about understanding climcate change.

the first one is to realise that earth is a closed environment, like a corked jar with a lamp shining on it: changes inside the jar always over time cumulate into other changes inside the jar. not a perfect analogy but reasonable i think, to see that what we do inside our jar does have an effect on its internal environment.

the second one is to understand that our survival relies on a range of conditions that exist on earth, and have existed for a long time, but didn't always. even without our influence, over time the conditions on earth would likely begin to change and drift further and further out of that range we depend on, due to the corked jar analogy. as a species we've survived conditions beyond this range before, like the little ice age. but our civilization is much more fragile and would not survive, along with a lot of people.

with these two understandings i'd posit that there's a fairly logical conclusion: we should focus our attention on preserving the conditions that are best suited for our life, whether they're being changed by our activities or natural events (probably both).

posts.com: Free will is evident to us by several means. For one, without it the idea of independent, objective knowledge is unfounded. Those in the sciences, for example, who insist that unprejudiced, unbiased findings trump prejudiced and biased ones implicitly accept that free will is real because only if our judgments can be free, can they be unbiased, independent, objective. Anyone who deplores racial, sexual or ethnic prejudice also implicitly accepts that people have free will and can exercise it badly or well. Racists allow themselves to judge by reference to irrelevant factors about another person and it is their capacity for free, independent perception and judgment that can serve to escape their prejudices, distinguish the relevant from the irrelevant. This is true with all other kinds of prejudice. So to deny free will is, implicitly, to endorse the unavoidability of prejudice, bias, subjectivity when it comes to human knowledge and understanding about the world.

Start by not wearing lenses when you can move the work closer to your face and see clearly. Cell phones are ideal for this (not kidding). Always read using light text on dark background. You'll feel a light tension when in the proper range for adaptation, and your eyesight will be noticeably improved the next day. Rinse and repeat, moving the work back as your eyesight improves, eventually moving on to plus lenses. Take frequent breaks, don't overdo it. Watch Becker's presentation about reversing myopia on youtube

>>15096868
Myopia, also known as nearsightedness, is a common refractive error that occurs when the eye is unable to focus on distant objects clearly. There are several ways to treat myopia, including the following:

Eyeglasses: Eyeglasses are a common and effective treatment for myopia. They correct vision by bending light rays to focus on the retina, allowing you to see clearly.

Contact lenses: Contact lenses work in the same way as eyeglasses, but they are worn directly on the surface of the eye. They are a good alternative to eyeglasses for some people.

Refractive surgery: Refractive surgery, such as LASIK, can correct myopia by reshaping the cornea to allow light rays to focus properly on the retina. This can be a permanent solution to myopia, but it is important to note that it is not without risks.

Orthokeratology: Orthokeratology, also known as "ortho-k," is a non-surgical treatment that uses special contact lenses to temporarily reshape the cornea and correct myopia. The lenses are typically worn overnight and removed during the day.

Vision therapy: Vision therapy is a type of treatment that aims to improve visual skills and eye coordination. It can be effective in reducing myopia in some cases.

It is important to discuss your treatment options with an eye care professional to determine the best course of action for your specific needs and preferences. They can help you weigh the pros and cons of each option and make an informed decision.

>>15103562
To be Griffiths is a Memebook for American students and thats just it. He covers superficial everything you need to know to start with QM, you wont understand much about QM with that book. Why? Because he goes the Schroedinger Wavemechanics approach but doesn't go deep into it. Speaking of which, there are several different approaches of Quamntum mechanics, or lets say, formalism you could follow. The most known is the Wavemechanics by Schroedinger, the second is the Heisenbergian Matrixmechanics, the third is less of a formalism but involves Functional Analysis and therefore a bit of Matrix mechanics and its more of Mathematical Physics. One significant approach are Path Integrals by Feynman, also you shouldn't avoid Relativistic Quantum Mechanics, but i guess thats something that comes last. As for QM Books, have a quick List: "Principles of Quantum Mechanics" by Dirac. "Matrix mechanics" by H.S. Green (He was a student of Max Born), "Quantum Physics: A Functional Integral Point of View" by James Glimm and Arthur Jaffe. "Quantum Mechanics and Path Integrals" by Richard Feynman. Also Lev Landaus "Relativistic Quantum Mechanics" out of his "Course of Theoretical Physics" though, there is a newer one which fused with the Quantumelectrodynamic book so beware, keep your eyes open for the older one. Also if you are in the mood i totally recommend the Feynman lectures which also include a book on QM. All of those books are very basic and teach you the various different approaches and formalisms. What i can't recommend, but will include is W. Paulis "Wellenmechanik" and Schroedingers "Abhandlungen zur Wellenmechanik", "Mathematical Foundations of Quantum Mechanics" by Von Neumann. There are probably a few more, don't know, i am not at home, and those i don't recommend are gems but only useful if you know german and if you get your hands on them, but they are all rather Mathematical PHysics books so they'll teach the math behind. Good luck anon with QM

There is a formula for the matrix that projects a vector onto a subspace. If your subspace is spanned by a set of vectors, you use those as the columns of a matrix A, and then [math]A(A^TA}^{-1}A^T[/math] (I forgot a T the first time) is your projection matrix

posts.com:
>>15089929
you need to sample at a rate of at least [math]2f[/math] to faithfully (kinda) capture a signal, where [math]f[/math] is the highest frequency contained in the signal. to capture a 1kHz sine wave, you need to sample at at least 2kHz. a square wave has infinitely high frequency components, so you can technically never truly capture a square wave, you can only be more and more reasonably certain its a square wave the higher you sample.
technically, you can never actually represent a continuous signal with discrete sampling. lets say you sample the peaks and troughs of a 1kHz sine wave (so youd be sampling at 2kHz). you could conclude that the signal is a 1kHz sine wave, but a sine wave of 2.5kHz would produce the exact same samples. these are called aliases, and the higher you sample, the farther out the aliases are; if you sample the 1kHz sine wave at 10kHz, the nearest alias is at 100kHz, i think. if youve ever seen video footage of something spinning really fast and noticed that the video made it look like it was spinning slowly, thats an example of aliasing.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliasing
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyquist_frequency
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyquist%E2%80%93Shannon_sampling_theorem

The longer you sum a convergent series the closer it approaches a number, called its limit. It never reaches a number greater than the limit, and it will always eventually go beyond a number that is less than the limit. Hence the limit is defined to be the value of the sum. The one in your picture is not convergent and has no limit, because it keeps oscillating.

>>15102181
In this example you dont. It doesn't converge.

It oscillates forever between 0 and 1, so it doesnt make sense to talk about it "at infinity"

But 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 + ... = 1 is very much a possible and real infinite sum.

That is it "converges", it gets closer and closer and closer to the right hand side of the equation.
Truth be told, it never reaches the right hand side but it gets "as close as we want" (little epsilon), so we just say the equality is exact.

1/2 is better than just an average value
1-x+x^2-x^3+... = 1/(1+x) for |x|<1
In the limit as x approaches 1 the sum goes to 1/2

Any sensible way of regularizing that sum is going to give you 1/2 as the answer

How the FUCK do flying pigs work? How do you even cook flying pigs?

"Well Anon, you capture them with nets. Like butterfly nets but much bigger, First you throw some corn into the air and when they come flying down you snag 'em with a net. Gotta be quick, but its worth it, them airborne hogs be plenty good eating"

This is essentially the same reasoning as applied to infinity. Its a fictitious concept made up out of thin air. Pure fantasy. It can only be considered to exist as a concept, it can be discussed, manipulated, much like our flying pigs, but there is nothing real about it. Dealing with issues arsing from the concept of infinity in mathematics is just the same as catching flying pigs. Internally the discussion makes complete sense. Capture flying pigs with nets, create an infinite sum. When you are dealing with fantasies anything can be made to make sense, even by following logical rules that exist in the real world.

The whole issue arose when people first began speculating about the number line. What if it goes on forever? Well, fuck, then if it goes on forever then we surely need a concept that provides a convenient and manipulable placeholder. >>15105794
Soil degradation.
The least sexy of all problems.
Most soils in temperate climates have become so depleted by overuse they can no longer sustain economic production of food without the massive addition of fertilizers. Most of which are artificial. Most of which have bottlenecks of critical elements coming from limited and ever diminishing supplies including petroleum based inputs. There are no replacements.

This is without mentioning the ongoing loss of soil through over grazing, over tilling, the damage of soil structure through intense farming and heavy machinery, the decline of the micro flora and fauna through the use of chemicals and the prevalence of mono-culture, and erosion due to man made activities. It takes tens of thousands of years by natural processes to replace a soil

Most people are so isolated from the basic realities of life that they cant grasp the fact that without fertile soil we will starve. Most are utterly unaware of our heavy dependence on artificial fertilizers, intense farming techniques, and heavy machinery to produce the yields which support the current world population. Not just the yields but also at the prices which makes food affordable to people.

It is estimated that if all artificial fertilizers were suddenly removed from the world supply the rate of food production would drop by between 80% to 90%. In other words most of the world's population would be facing starvation, with no one to provide any aid from a surplus.

Lets not mention the decline of global fish stocks.

This will not happen suddenly, of course, but it will happen eventually, slowly, and then at an ever increasing rate, until the global population matches the natural carrying capacity of the remaining fertile soils. I.E. around 10 to 20% of current levels.

This is a situation that many soil scientists have been aware of for the past half century or more. But no one wants to know. Its not sexy.

LETS TALK ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE!

The concept of a black hole is based on incomplete or flawed assumptions about the nature of the universe. The laws of physics break down at the event horizon of a black hole, and therefore it is not possible for such an object to exist.

The existence of black holes are also violates certain principles or symmetries that are thought to be fundamental to the way the universe works. Black holes violate the principle of energy conservation, or that they violate certain symmetries of space and time that are believed to be intrinsic to the fabric of the cosmos.

There is currently no scientific evidence or experimental data that suggests the existence of spatial dimensions beyond three. He failed to understand the concept of necessary and sufficient conditions. Yes, consciousness has the effect that e.g. we talk about and publish papers about it. Conversely however, from the fact that someone wrote a paper about consciousness we cannot conclude that they are indeed conscious.

Undergoing HRT and sex reassignment surgery will turn a person who was assigned male at birth into a woman. Can we conclude now that every woman was assigned male at birth? No, because there also exist the unfortunate cis-women who never had to struggle with their gender identity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15105951 (cont.)
Part two is just a bunch of whining and arguing from consequences, thankfully it's pretty short.
Part three starts out as if he'll try to find common ground between physicalism and non-physicalism:
>Nonetheless, one of the rewards of my persistent arguments with zombies has been a thumbnail sketch of a way to think about consciousness that might perhaps be satisfying to both zombies and zagnets.
(A zagnet is apparently the opposite of a zombie i.e. someone like Jason who thinks there's something non-physical about his own consciousness)
Now he does have a thesis, apparently:
>Here's my thought: Consciousness is the choice of which abstractions we experience, out of an infinite number of ways of slicing the continuity of the universe. It's the feeling of existence that is the choice.
As far as I can tell from this part, he actually thinks there is some magical property of our universe that singles out one layer of abstraction from all the possible ways of looking at the information implicit in brains, and this singling out is somehow (he doesn't elaborate) what leads to subjective experience.
What's funny is that this line of thought is actually very similar to computationalists who wonder about which of all the possible mappings between a physical brain and a computation that implements consciousness should be the "actual" or "privileged" one (see pdf related for an example of such arguments). So my conclusion is that Lanier is about equally confused as the computationalists he's critiquing.

I'd say prime numbers are far more useless. Yes they are used in encryption, but there are other methods of encryption that don't use primes and are arguably better like lattice based methods and other post quantum methods. But primes aren't used in encryption because primes are great, they're used because mathematicians are too retarded to work out a way to factor them efficiently. People are actually paid money to research prime numbers all day, it's laughable. Sure maybe have one or two guys looking into them but instead there's dozens or even hundreds of them and they treat primes as some kind of miracle of mathematics and they must all be found like they're Pokemon or some shit. I liken it to say a video game speedrunner looking for all the glitches in a game. People that follow the speedrunning scene of that game think the top runner is some kind of genius pushing extreme boundaries and blowing minds by discovering things never thought possible. In reality outside their tiny group nobody gives a fuck and think they're idiots for wasting their time because nothing that comes out of the group is useful or meaningful in any way other than to their own little group. But for mathematics the amazing genius aspect has leaked out into the public and there's a notion that these people searching for something useless are of the highest order of intelligence. I'd say something like inventing a novel product on your own and turning it into a billion dollar businesses without cheating or scamming anyone takes far more intelligence and it would be actually useful too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15105849
>Algebra
Start with Lang's algebra. It doesn't require any prerequisites, so should be a gentle start.
>Precalculus
I don't even know what that means.
>Geometry
Well you first need a good grounding in topology, so go ahead with Munkres' book on topology. It might also be nice to see some algebraic topology, so since you're time constrained, I'd recommend May's concise course in algebraic topology. Next, just jump right into Lee's book on topological manifolds, followed by his book on smooth manifolds, and then for the more algebraic side of geometry, just read Hartshorne's book on algebraic geometry.
>Calculus
Again, you're time-constrained, so just jump right into PMA by Rudin. If that's to easy for you, go to real and complex analysis by the same author.
>Statistics
Having already read real and complex analysis, you'll have a good enough grounding in measure theory to learn some basic statistics with Schervish's book called theory of statistics.
>Linear algebra
The nice thing about this outline is that you'll already pick up plenty of linear algebra a la Lang's book.

This should take about a day or so. If you prefer to take your time, it might take up to a week.

That's a good explanation of why time travel to the past is not possible according to our current understanding of physics. The concept of time travel to the past is based on the idea of going faster than the speed of light and reaching a point in the past before you started your journey. However, the laws of physics as we currently understand them do not allow for anything to travel faster than the speed of light, so this type of time travel is not possible.

There are also other issues with the idea of time travel to the past, such as the grandfather paradox, which states that if you were able to travel back in time and kill your own grandfather, you would not exist in the present. This paradox illustrates the problems and inconsistencies that would arise if time travel to the past were possible.

Overall, while the concept of time travel is interesting and has been explored in science fiction and popular culture, it is not currently possible based on our current understanding of the laws of physics.

To put it somewhat poetically, we could simply forget what it was that made us us.
This could quickly cascade into a feedback loop and, at the end, result in human beings that are unrecognisable from any biological being.

>we barely understand the most elementary functions of the brain, and are nowhere near such (figurative and literal) surgical precision "psychomodding".
>But how viable would this become if we actually just existed as code on a computer?
That's why I predict the interface will come first. Even a full brain emulation is just a black box unless you understand how neurons generate mental phenomena. You don't need to understand the neurons, however, to give them an interface. They already know how to grow new connections in response to reward stimuli, so it's simply a case of providing a new I/O. This has already been done to a limited extent with paralysed people, who can learn how to control a machine using implants in the motor cortex. The more you practice with the interface the better you get at using it, without ever needing to know how your neurons are achieving these gains.
>>15102412
>We may find that emotional modules are valuable shortcuts to things that otherwise consume too much compute.
>you could consult your envy module and see which of their two lifestyles makes you most envious
I suspect that is the case for all forms of progress. The modern world places a lot of value on suppressing instinct, with something like envy being seen as innately primitive and dangerous to civilization. This isn't actually based on evidence, but taken on faith as a kind of creed. You could show people all the anthropological and evolutionary-biological data on why these dangerous instincts are necessary, but they will still assume they are better off without them.
The zoomer generation may be the beginning of a break with this trend, given the fluidity of their online extremism. They can be far-left today (envy, status-seeking), far-right tomorrow (tribalism, in-group) and religious fanatics the next day (purity, disgust). In other words, the the high connectivity of living online is reintroducing forgotten instincts to their brains.

>This might suggest the counterintuitive conclusion that unchecked immigration might be harmful to the native population of a society
Following up on this: One could actually try to get a way to measure the maximum tolerable immigration rate by looking at the average rate of user assimilation.

That might be an interesting research project provided you have a large enough dataset of posts and their authors.
First you get a list of communities. You calculate their immigration rate and you calculate the average rate of user assimilation by semantically comparing the posts of new people over time to the posts of older ones.
Then you calculate the emigration rate of older users.
Then you basically plot emigration rate of every community by immigration rate and assimilation rate (3d plot) and look for a cutoff.

Of course you would need to account for survivorship bias (the older people staying in a community will like it more there, so those older people that you use for comparing the posts of newer ones already are more like them).

>>15103774
The issue with a place that allows for more freedom of expression is that you’ll inevitably get unhinged folks. When 4chan was smaller and the internet more a place to escape reality, this place excelled in being a cultural powerhouse for the internet’s younger years due to it’s relaxed rules. Although this place has been notorious for its degeneracy since its conception, the freedom, anonymity, and ease of use allowed people to be creative and spread ideas and memes. Before people figured out how to monetize and push agendas on the internet, it was mainly ran by people who just wanted to make things for the sake of making things. I wouldn’t say the modern state of 4chan, and the internet as a whole, changed over night but the tipping point between the esoterical, nerdy environment and the mass audience, low quality spamming occurred around 2016 with the election. Although there were signs of the internet being used to polarize and manipulate groups, the 2016 election truly showed everyone how effective the internet was at sowing discontent and pushing propaganda. 4chan, emphasising freedom of speech, attracted a lot of unhinged folks. People who’d take advantage and ruin everything. For every Average Joe, there’s a malicious Alex who forces everyone to look over their shoulder. I like to think that most people here aren’t malicious or trying to push their stupid agendas on some science board, yet the bad faith posters are much more vocal and beacon themselves to attract other unhinged individuals. It’s the paradox of tolerance. If you’re tolerant of everyone, you’ll eventually get shitheads that ruin it for everyone else. It’s why I support gatekeeping and moderation to an extent. You have to filter the folks who’ll just post low quality or de-rail a discussion for their own personal agendas. I’ve been frequently going to older forum websites to experience some more mature, in-depth discussion, but their numbers keep shrinking.

But we also use what you are talking about. It's called momentum.
If the net force F applied to a particle is constant, and is applied for a time interval Δt, the momentum of the particle changes by an amount: Δ p = F Δ t. So you could derive a complex formula for the total change in momentum but this is useless on a day to day basis. You want, in your example, to know how much calories it burns in the end and this is linked to movement because moving a mass changes it's potential and this takes up energy. Even if you move it horizontally your body constantly has to "fight" gravity which will end up costing energy to keep the potential.

>>15099752
I worked as a data analyst for roughly a year and a half. The day-to-day is pretty mundane. A data analyst (i.e. not a data scientist nor a data engineer) is really just someone who makes reports. For example, the data engineer may build the back-end data infrastructure to create a model. The data scientist then uses that infrastructure to create a model. Let's say he makes a cluster models that classifies all clients into categories A, B and C. You, as the data analyst, may be tasked with updating the monthly report that counts exactly how many clients are in each category, how much it changed from the previous month, and maybe you are expected to add in a couple of bullet points of your own 'analysis' of why that may have happened.

Then, when you finish that, you probably have a backlog of other 20 reports you are responsible for updating. This is not necessarily bad nor good. But it is considered a pretty entry level position that does mainly grunt work.

Look up the salary range on glassdoor or something similar and then lowball a little bit, you can always backtrack later and say "I got another offer for X amount" or "I think the company is a great fit, but upon reviewing the contract I have to revise the previous salary range, and of course it's negotiable".

>>15099415
>Is mathematical engineering a meme master?
Low IQ heavily opinionated undergrad here. I get the appeal of jumping into a general engineering program (with a fancy-sounding name like Physics Engineering or Mathematical Engineering) during the first 2 years of your bachelor's studies, but I imagine that after 2 years of taking math and Physics courses you would have started getting the ball rolling regarding what you want to work in, and what you want to make.
If you want to work on buildings and bridges, you can study civil engineering. If you want to work on motor engines, you can study mechanical engineering. If you want to work on electrical stuff, you can do electrical engineering. If you want to work on chemical processes, you can study chemical engineering. If you want to work on manufacturing and supply systems in general, you can study industrial engineering.
There are some areas of research that require knowledge from various engineering fields, like materials science (which has both mechanical and chemical engineers working on it, and impacts the work of civil and electrical engineers as well), automatized manufacturing systems(which involve machines commanded by digital electronic systems, that have to be put in coordination with a series of materials, set procedures, an output, etc. set up by an industrial project manager), energy, high fidelity communications systems, and semiconductors (which involve electronics and chemistry knowledge, and may require the cooperation of people with modern physics knowledge and people capable of implementing high precision manufacturing tasks).
I can't imagine what a mathematical engineering master's degree project would involve, other than making some computer-based simulations of some physical phenomenon or non-existent apparatus undergoing some purely hypothetical modelled scenario.
>"Bro, but look at dem fancy curves and stats tables"
What would that be useful for?

There are not only multiple answers, but infinitely many. The solution set is a line (one dimensional and infinite).

There's only 1 solution. Setting up a system of equations that way only constrains the problem to angles, but we assume we're dealing with a square so we constrain the sides to be equal lengths as well.
There can only be "infinite solutions" if it's not a square and we allow infinite ratios of side lengths. Pic related has angles that satisfy your equations but obviously it's not a square so it doesn't count.

By visual inspection it should be very intuitive there is only 1 solution if we assume a square because the angles can't change or else the problem's given 40 deg or 80 deg angles must change.

5 equations 5 unknowns and it should only have the same solution for any given side length if I'm not mistaken.

This is not always the case. Sometimes it's the other way around actually, for example patients who are found unconscious after suffering trauma are always treated as if they had cervical spine injury.
When this is the case it's usually because benign conditions are also the most common ones so it makes sense to consider them first. The general rule in diagnosis is to consider the most common conditions rather than the most benign ones.

>>15104539
>i dont get the worry over spike proteins in the blood, its literally just a fake "key" the virus uses to go into cells and infect them
Sort of. While the S1 binding to cells doesn't result in new viral particles, it does cause inflammation and potential clotting. It's probably a matter of quantity, and low levels may not be a huge concern. The bigger issue is how many of the LNPs reach circulation. In some people, they may primarily enter cells in the shoulder to deposit the mRNA payload, which was the goal. In others, if a blood vessel is hit or there's capillary leakage, the LNPs will disseminate and transport the mRNA to cells away from the shoulder. Now you have a double whammy because you're likely going to see a larger amount of S1 sub units in circulation, as well as having cells targeted by the immune system for apoptosis that are unable to regenerate (i.e. myocardium of the heart).

As for actual infection, higher numbers of S1 are associated with disease severity, though it's hard to say if the spike and S1 in the blood stream is the actual culprit, or if it's a matter of very high viral load resulting in more spike and S1 reaching circulation.

posts.com:
>>15082231
Unless you're a genius math savant (you're most likely not, seeing as you're asking a question about learning math on 4chan of all places), you might be able to cover little more than the bases of real analysis and calculus.
Far too many people have started learning calculus on their own with the intention of getting into real analysis and have gotten stuck on limits and/or differentiation.
I'd recommend you to pay very close attention to every subject introduced in your book/course, go through as many exercises as possible (with particular emphasis on hard-looking ones), and to try to use various resources if necessary for the sake of getting a good grasp of many concepts and techniques you might have to use. It might not hurt to learn set theory and the basics of symbolic logic, but it might be better to refrain from looking into other branches of math until you've gotten a good, solid understanding of Calculus.
Most university students take real analysis after 3 semesters of Calculus, so try not to rush through it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15087748
It's still true, but the proof is substantially more complex than the two-colour case.
Colour in the positive integers arbitrarily using three colours. van der Waerden's theorem says that, if we consider a large enough amount of them, we can find a monochromatic arithmetic progression of any size.
So we are forced to have such a progression of arbitrary length on the x-axis; assume without loss of generality that the points in this progression are red. This means that any point equidistant from any pair of these must be either green or blue; these points will form an equilateral triangle above the axis.
Now consider the bottom row of this smaller triangle. We can apply the theorem once again to show that there must be another monochromatic progression here, which we'll arbitrarily set to be blue. If we've coloured in enough points on the x-axis, this progression must have at least three points A, B, and C. Let D be equidistant from A and B, E equidistant from A and C, and F equidistant from B and C. Since A, B, and C are all blue, none of these three can be, so they must all be red or green. However, any of these three is also equidistant from a pair of points on the x-axis, so none of them can be red, either. And they can't be green, because they form an equilateral triangle with each other.
So we're left to conclude is that such a triangle will always exist, although the numbers involved are big enough that it's probably best to not brute-force it.

This proof is kinda fun bros:

For all natural numbers a,b: prove that if 2b divides 2a and 2b does not divide a, then a is congruent to b mod 2n.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15096014
Absolutely not!
For a prime p, the p-adic integers is an infinite ring of characteristic 0. It contains the integers, some rationals (the ones with a denominator not divisible by p), and even complex algebraic numbers.

Every p-adic integer has a unique representation as a (possibly infinite) string of numbers from the set {0, 1, ..., p-1}. If it's an infinite string, it goes off infinitely to the left.
If you start indexing the places from 0, then the nth place tells how many copies of p^n you have. So it's essentially base p representation.

For example, in the 2-adics, 10111 represents 23 (base 10), so basically binary. The infinite string ...111111 represents the number -1 (base 10). (Try to figure out how you can represent 1/3 in the 2-adics; it's just a geometric series)

For each n, the ring Z/(p^n)Z is a "rough approximation" of Z_p; for every p-adic integer, you can just take the first n digits from the right an get an element of Z/(p^n)Z (it's a homomorphism).

It's a very fun topic to learn about, and you can use it to prove Mosky's theorem (that no square can be split into an odd amount of equally-sized triangles).

>if 2b divides 2a
So b divides a, or a = db.
>then a is congruent to b mod 2b.
That's equivalent to saying that a = k2b + b = (2k+1)b, i.e. a is an odd multiple of b.

Since 2b does not divide a, we have that a/(2b) = d/2 is not an integer. So d is not even, and must be odd.

>>15096131
>if I say "ring Z_n of integers"
No, that would denote the ring of n-adic integers, if n is a general natural number and not necessarily a prime. (same as p-adics, but not necessarily an integral domain anymore)
Either say "let Z_n denote the ring of integers mod n", or just use "Z/nZ" which is always clear.
>my notation of the ring of integers,
That's a third, entirely different object from both "the ring of integers mod n" and "the ring of n-adic integers".


To summarize and make it clear:
>Z is the ring of integers, and is the set {..., -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, ...} which you learned in high school. It is countably infinite.
>Z/nZ, sometimes denoted Z_n, is the ring of integers modulo n, and it is the set {[0], [1], [2], ..., [n-1]} of equivalence classes of integers, modulo the relation of a ~ b if a-b is a multiple of n. It is a finite set with n elements.
>Z_n is the set of n-adic integers, which is the set of strings I described earlier. It is uncountably infinite.

Just be careful with your words.

Fractional Distance: The Topology of the Real Number Line with Applications to the Riemann Hypothesis
>https://vixra.org/abs/2111.0072
>http://gg762.net/d0cs/papers/Fractional_Distance_v6-20210521.pdf
Recent analysis has uncovered a broad swath of rarely considered real numbers called real numbers in the neighborhood of infinity. Here we extend the catalog of the rudimentary analytical properties of all real numbers by defining a set of fractional distance functions on the real number line and studying their behavior. The main results of are (1) to prove with modest axioms that some real numbers are greater than any natural number, (2) to develop a technique for taking a limit at infinity via the ordinary Cauchy definition reliant on the classical epsilon-delta formalism, and (3) to demonstrate an infinite number of non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function in the neighborhood of infinity. We define numbers in the neighborhood of infinity as Cartesian products of Cauchy equivalence classes of rationals. We axiomatize the arithmetic of such numbers, prove all the operations are well-defined, and then make comparisons to the similar axioms of a complete ordered field. After developing the many underlying foundations, we present a basis for a topology.

posts.com:
>>15104098
Oh, wait, I'm blind.
[math]\frac{ab}{a+b}=k\to{}ka+kb=ab\to{}ab-ka=a(k-b)=kb[/math]
Since a,b are coprime, all of a's prime factors must be contained within k, so [math]a|k[/math].
Similarly, all of b's prime factors must also be factors of [math](k-b)[/math], which implies that [math]b|(k-b)[/math], so [math]b|k[/math].
But this implies that [math]k\geq{a}[/math] and [math]k\geq{b}[/math], so [math]ka+kb\geq{}ba+ab=2ab=ab[/math], a contradiction unless either a=b=1 or one of them is 0, neither of which is valid under the initial assumption.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15104211
Sorry, here's a correction. You need to find an orthogonal nxn B such that Z^T will send the first column of B^T to e_1 . You can achieve this by taking B^T to have first column Z^T^{-1} (e_1) , then extending this to an orthonormal basis.

Here Z is the nxn orthogonal matrix whose columns are all the z's , with z_1 through z_t first .

And ^T means transpose.

Now the first t columns of BZ should be the basis you want, since the first row of BZ should be e_1^T .

posts.com:
You can get a rational parametrization of the unit circle using complex numbers over Q.

z€ C(Q), z≡ a+bi, Q(z)≡ a^2+b^2

N(Z)≡ z^2/Q(z)= (a^2-b^2)/(a^2+b^2)+2abi/(a^2+b^2)

Q(N(z))= |N(z)|= 1, but We have avoided irrational numbers by using Q(z) instead of |z|, so to keep N(z) a unit complex number we needed to square the numerator z as well giving us z^2/Q(z).

Our next step is to make N a function with a single rational parameter, to do this we can use the property that N(𝛌z)=N(z), 𝛌≠0, we can divide z by a in N.

N(a+bi)= N(1+bi/a)= N(1+ti), t=b/a

e_{c}(t)≡ N(1+ti)= (1-t^2)/(1+t^2)+2ti/(1+t^2)

e_{c}(t) is the rational complex number parametrization of the unit circle, the c in the subscript is for complex. To get the rational parametrization for points we will need to define two functions.

C(t)≡ (1+t^2)/(1+t^2) and S(t)≡ 2t/(1+t^2)

e(t)≡ [C(t), S(t)]= [(1+t^2)/(1+t^2), 2t/(1+t^2)]

C(t) and S(t) are just the "real" and imaginary components of e_{c} respectively.

If you have e_{c}(t) and e_{c}(u) then the value of the perimeter e_{c}(t)·e_{c}(u) is t⊕u≡ (t+u)/(1-tu), ⊕ is circle addition.

the lammermeier product of two points A and B on a conic is defined to be the intersection of the conic and the line through a point O (which we have chosen) , which is parallel to the line through A and B; written as A*B. (A*B)O || AB, O is on the conic.

If we are looking at on the the lammermeier product of unit circle where O≡ [1, 0] then e(t)*e(u) is isomorphic to e_{c}(t)·e_{c}(u).

e(t)*e(u)= e(t⊕u)= e((t+u)/(1-tu)), e_{c}(t)·e_{c}(u)= e_{c}(t⊕u)=e_{c}((t+u)/(1-tu))

You can learn more in the attached document. I fuckin' hate English.

>>15083935
The sub-quark layer exists virtually in calculation.

We make assumptions about the behavior of that layer, based on observations, but we can not physically observe any interactions in that layer from within space-time through any known means as of today.

When we apply symmetry theories and gauge theory in quantum physical calculations, the interim steps in the calculations are assumed to be occurring simultaneously either outside of space-time entirely, or existing solely in an array of possibilities within space-time contained within quantum fields.

Since we can't observe information outside of space-time, these types of theories lead to quantum assumptions being tested in both ways. Either under the assumption that there are local field interactions that fully contain the entirety of the interaction and/or that the interactions occur outside of the locality of space-time itself.

The math tends to work out, either way.
The first person who can genuinely come up with an experimental test to prove definitively that it is one or the other, is pretty much a guaranteed Nobel Prize recipient, since it would cut the workload of all those working in the quantum and sub-atomic particle interaction space by at least half, instantly.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15105516
>What would null state be in bits?
Not him, but if you're talking about C, the null pointer appears in pointer contexts when you use "an integer constant expression with the value 0, or such an expression cast to type void *". You can write such an expression yourself or use the NULL macro, which will be defined to such an expression.

But note that even though you're throwing around such 0 expressions in your code, the actual bit representation of a null pointer doesn't have to be all zero bits. On most desktop architectures, its representation will be all zero bits, but it doesn't have to be.

In quantum biology, researchers have studied the use of quantum entanglement in bird navigation and the role of quantum effects in the sense of smell in certain animals. These studies have shown that quantum physics can provide insight into a wide range of natural phenomena and has practical applications in fields such as biology and engineering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://thewire.in/the-sciences/what-is-quantum-biology

Schrödinger and Niels Bohr were early proponents of the integration of quantum mechanics and biology, but their ideas did not gain widespread support. Quantum biology has remained a neglected field, with little interest from physicists, chemists, or biologists. Quantum phenomena such as tunnelling and entanglement have been studied in carefully controlled experiments that must be insulated from noise, or any unwanted disturbance that interferes with the system's performance. These experiments are often conducted at low temperatures to minimize vibrations in the instruments and maintain the quantum nature of the system.


It is believed that some birds, such as European Robins, use proteins called cryptochromes in their eyes to navigate using quantum entanglement. These proteins respond to light by creating a pair of particles that are connected and oscillate between different quantum states. A magnetic field forces the entangled pair to spend more time in a specific quantum state, creating a signal for the brain to use as a magnetic field sensor. This theory has been supported by various measurements and has been applied to the study of enzyme catalysis, photosynthesis, and avian navigation. Researchers are also investigating the potential role of quantum effects in smell, the origin of consciousness, and the origin of life. It is important to note that classical and quantum mechanics are human-created labels and that nature does not necessarily follow these distinctions. Quantum effects may be present in living systems and can be observed outside of carefully controlled laboratory experiments.

There has been debate over the interpretation of oscillatory signals known as "quantum coherence" observed in the study of pigment-protein complexes in photosynthesis, and whether they represent "nontrivial quantum effects" that are necessary for photosynthetic function. Some argue that the focus on coherence detracts from the fact that light harvesting is largely governed by slower processes on time scales of tens of picoseconds. This review aims to assess the role of quantum coherence in photosynthetic light harvesting and to clarify the definitions of "coherence" and "quantumness" in the context of ultrafast spectroscopy of molecular systems.

Quantum biology is an interdisciplinary field that explores the role of quantum mechanical phenomena, such as superposition and entanglement, in biological systems. Some of the recent discoveries in this field include:

1. Quantum coherence in photosynthesis: It has been found that quantum coherence, a phenomenon in which the quantum states of a system overlap, plays a role in the energy transfer process in photosynthesis. This discovery helps explain the high efficiency of photosynthesis in plants, which converts sunlight into chemical energy.

2. Quantum tunneling in enzyme reactions: Enzymes are proteins that catalyze chemical reactions in the body. It has been found that some enzymes use quantum tunneling, a phenomenon in which a particle can pass through an energy barrier, to speed up chemical reactions.

3. Quantum effects in bird navigation: Some birds, such as the European robin, use the Earth's magnetic field to navigate during migration. It has been suggested that quantum effects, such as entanglement, may play a role in this process.

4.Quantum effects in the sense of smell: It has been suggested that quantum mechanical phenomena may play a role in the way in which our brains process smells. Specifically, it has been proposed that quantum coherence may be involved in the way in which odorant molecules bind to receptors in the nose.

These are just a few examples of the many exciting discoveries that have been made in the field of quantum biology.

I'm not even American and I feel like the Imperial System is unfairly hated.

I've done my fair share of blue collar jobs and the same pattern of management trying to tardwrangle the workers into using metric measurements and the workers reverting back to Imperial when the pressure is off happens over and over again. For scaffolding, one company started making the workers cut all tubing at 0.5meter increments instead of 1 foot increments in an attempt to put a stop workers using imperial. The system clashed with the rest of the imperial cut tubing and lead to much hardship in planning jobs, especially as the 0.5meter increments in sizes are too large, meaning you're pointlessly having to cut extra tube for specialized jobs. Maybe it's easier for pricing, and for large jobs I can understand Structural Engineer Chads getting pissed off having to do the conversions (but not really, software handles that pretty well now I'm sure). But 98% of our work is at the low level where you guestimate your way through.

I don't think the imperial system is "better", but for offhand estimation when you're in a rush and you're doing a practical job, feet and inches are just more practical sizes than centimeters and meters. I know for cooking imperial measurements are still beloved, and other certain specialized trades like Tailors still use imperial measurements.

I feel like the system has its place in history, and it's fine to let blue collar workers keep on using it. I don't get the absolute hatred for it.

I think an important thing to keep in mind, is that bullying does not only exist in humans. Other animals use it to establish and maintain pecking orders and breeding rights. Since humans are mostly free from natural selection, we're mostly affected by sexual and artificial selection. The being the case, it's reasonable that a mechanism of behavior so widely observed in nature, is still practiced despite our increased intelligence, and our ability to contemplate morality.

In order to better understand this behavior, I think it's best to start by establishing that geography has a significant impact on culture. I.e, a group of people settle in an area, determine what the most comfortable existence they can establish is, and then create a culture that justifies that existence, while demonizing detracting behaviors, and encouraging behavior that supports the aforementioned culture.

How does bullying factor into all this? While no one likes the idea of being bullied, harassed, etc, we all enjoy upward social mobility, or at the very least, stability in regards to our current social position. By degrading others, especially in social settings such as school, a bully is able to publically announce their social standing, as at the very least, being above that of the person they are harassing. Most people never do anything to prevent the bullying of another, because that action introduces the opportunity for downward social mobility, with little in the way of possible rewards. Although we all like to believe we would do something heroic when we see wrongdoing, most psychological and sociological evidence points to the contrary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15103387
It is also unsurprising that most bullies tend to not be extremely successful, and the most victims suffer longterm negative consequences. The type of person attracted to bullying will typically be a person that cannot establish a high social standing with physical ability or intelligence, so by demeaning others, especially those with traits they lack, they are able to create a level of social standing (albeit temporarily) usually unobtainable to them. Regarding the victims of bullying, this attitude of "it toughens you up", is just ridiculous. While we can always expect negative social interactions to be a part of our experience as a social species, being harassed and abused is not to be expected, as it is maladaptive behavior.

I think it's also important to make a distinction between bullying that exists to elevate the social standing of the abuser, and the natural "demonization" of behavior that is seen as culturally inappropriate. As I mentioned before, all cultures seek to encourage some behavior and prevent others, and to the end, social settings have an unspoken code of conduct which is to be followed, or one will face social consequences. And these consequences tend to be focused on ostracization, instead of intentional physical or psychological abuse. As an example, if you were at store, and a person walked in dressed as an actual clown, most people would be uncomfortable around them, and treat them differently as a result, since they're violating social norms. This type of bullying is useful for society, as it promotes social cohesion, a sense of normalcy, and shared values, whereas the aforementioned type of bullying, has not postive consequences

posts.com:
>>14938339
>Is there a definitive physics text for undergraduate calculus based physics 1 and 2?
No, they're all more or less the same. The standard in my state when I did my undergrad was Halliday, Resnik, and Krane. The standard at the school I'm teaching at is Serway. For better or worse every intro physics sequence follows basically the same pattern: Physics I - mechanics and thermo, Physics II - E&M and modern. And all the books go through basically the same structure and routine for introducing topics:
You start with kinematics because it's the basis for all the vector and calculus language you're going to be using for describing motion later on, then forces and the laws of motion as a setup for the rest of linear dynamics (work and energy, impulse and momentum, etc). Then rotational motion, equilibrium, and dynamics to gradually introduce and build up the background needed to describe and combine translation and rotation. Then fluids, thermo, waves, sound.

E&M starts out by introducing charge and Coulomb's Law, basic integration methods for Gauss's Law/Poisson's Equation, circuits, more circuits, magnetic fields, forces, and induction, Faraday and Ampere, really gross Biot-Savart Law integration, then EM waves, optics, and a smidge of modern stuff if there's time.

Some undergraduate courses do a four-course sequence where they split off all the thermal stuff into one semester and all the quantum/relativity stuff into another, but I think the most common practice now is to give thermal the short end of the stick and lump contemporary topics into a Physics III or a Modern Physics course.

tl;dr - Just pick whatever's cheapest or whatever you can pirate easiest.

posts.com:
>>15034298
No, it's actually a terrible list that will demotivate you. Several of the "prerequisite" books there are more advanced than the "final" calculus books.

If you're starting below a basic highschool level you will be much better off with a highschool level text, or something like khanacademy if you need immediate feedback drills. Look to see if any local schools run adult remedial classes if you're really serious. Especially when you're just starting out it's very useful to have access to an instructor.

If you can handle highschool algebra and geometry well enough, I like Epp's Discrete Mathematics for a gentle first introduction to more abstract "mathy" mathematics. It's very well presented and should be accessible to a motivated student, even if their background is a little weak.

>>15099462
Totally free will is contradictory. If you can have your cake and eat it too, both go to a party and stay home to read on the same night, move upwards and downwards at the same time, etc. you cannot make choices. Choices imply a choosing between things, but absolute freedom means no choice excludes anything. Absolute freedom entails an absolute constraint on one's ability to select for and against various options. One's actions have no effect, as absolute freedom implies they can always be reversed, and thus absolute freedom is absolute constraint.

This contradiction is only resolved when freedom sublates constraint and our choices begin to have determinate meaning.

Obviously we are not fully free. I can't open my door in Montana and step into a Paris street, or take flight like a bird. But freedom is only possible in such a constrained process.

I used to think that way, but then I asked the question.

If I can negotiate a presence in the wider universe, surely my free will can as well. If atoms, particles can negotiate their existence away from the universe, then so too can I. If my chemistry can, then so must I as well.

That's not to suggest a universe defying entity controls the body and makes supernatural moves, but that I'm not just a universe, not just a part, but an active part that can exert the will through the body's active control in relation to the passive forces around the body.

So not saying "free will" vs universe, but rather free will as part of the universe, within a framework that allows partitioning of the universe into parts.

>interpreting statistical modelling as conceptual fact
Wave functions are just a useful mathematical description. Particles have a definite state at any given instant, but because the states are so sensitive to perturbation one cannot know what its particular state is at a given moment unless it interacts with something. Entangling particles through some quantifiable interaction and then measuring the state of one only lets you know the state of the other after that initial interaction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I also think this one is useful
https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/128848/why-would-classical-correlation-in-bells-experiment-be-a-linear-function-of-ang
Key points are the linear/cosine graph in the question, and the 2nd answer which gives a simpler but sufficient variation:
>Bell proved an over-general result that is unnecessarily hard to understand. You don't need a continuum of measurement angles to get a nonclassical result, just three. With three angles, the argument above shows that there are only 23=8 possible "answer strategies" for the boxes, which we can write UUU, UUD, UDU, ..., DDD (where U means the first box says "up" and the second "down", and D is the reverse). Two of those, UUU and DDD, lead to the boxes always disagreeing. The other six are all equivalent under permutations and exchange of U and D, and they lead to the boxes agreeing 2/3 of the time when the angles are different. So 2/3 agreement is the highest possible in a classical world. But in a quantum world, measuring Bell-pair electrons along axes of 0°, 120° and 240° gives agreement 3/4 of the time.

I just wanna chime in here and hopefully clarify the whole thing OP

The Copenhagen interpretation implies the particles exist in superpositions of states that collapse upon measurement. To be specific, this means the natural state for quantum particles is a superposition of all possibilities. Mathematically, we represent an unmeasured particle as a superposition function which shows us the probability of a particle being measured with any given value of any given property. This means we have a graph of x, y, and probability all plotted on their own axis (or you may say, as their own dimension!).
I want you to now imagine the probability function as an actual property of the particle, like mass or charge, or x-position. When we measure the particle's momentum, and 'collapse this wave function', mathematically we are performing a Fourier transform on the probability (or wave) function. This means we are taking information about a function and projecting it into another dimension. In normal math, this would be the frequency dimension, but in quantum mechanics we transform the wave into a new function in 'momentum space'! The Copenhagen interpretation says we have fundamentally altered this particle by transforming the wave function.

Now that a particle was measured, and the wave function collapsed: we can perform experiments with this particle and predict the outcome 100% of the time. We have altered the state of the particle by measuring it; no longer is a superposition.

An entangled pair means (mathematically) that we can describe both particles with a single wave function; imagine two sine waves, summed. Therefore, by measuring one particle, you have actually measured both and (spooky action:) collapsed both wave functions! You have influenced the entangled counterpart as if the information traveled faster than light - telling the distant particle to now exist with a collapsed wave function.
However, information itself is still capped at c.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15104677
>>15105305
>However, information itself is still capped at c.
I just want to clarify:
Here I am saying you now know something about that very distant particle, so what can you do?
Well nothing.
Sure, you know something about it, but the only way to act on that knowledge is to convey information about the particle to the location that other particle exists at. For instance, maybe you send an electrical signal to the particle, or maybe you send light rays which communicate information to another lab team; it doesn't matter.
That information you send is capped at the speed of light. Therefore, although something is happening faster than light, no information has traveled faster than light.

I took a 1000-level sociology class in college. The teacher was very good, Rosalia Solorzano I think was her name. (She told me her teachers in school had always wanted to call her Rosalie and that she obstinately resisted with her stern declarations on what her name was.) The material was interesting in general and I learned about one thing in there that I think about to this day: the social construction of reality. It's a sociological principle that says for practical purposes "reality" is determined more strongly by people's opinions on what is real than by what is actually real. There's some more nuance to it but I think the concept is profound. I'm very glad that I learned about it and it influences my thinking to this day.

I also learned the words "aenima" and "animus" which I used one of my papers. I think I liked it mostly because it was a survey of the fundamentals of sociology and I don't doubt OP's points would have increased in weight in the upper division courses.

Just looking to find out something about torque, I have been trying to wrap my head around it but can't figure it out. I asked the Ai and they can't seem to figure it out either, they just keep regurgitating the same nonsense about there being insufficient data of the shape and materials.

Consider the following situation: There are 2 duplicate 4 inch square rods, made of the same substance. I put one in a vice and turn it with a wrench, the wrench is 1 inch deep into the rod. After 10 lbft of torque, the metal rod breaks.

I perform the next test with the 2nd rod, this time putting it 1 inch deep into a drill. Attached to the rod is an robust drum cylinder that has a weight of only 2 lbs, and a radius of 1 ft. On its horizontal radius is a weight attached of 10 lbs, the weight wants to rotate the drum clockwise, while the dirll wants to rotate the rod counterclockwise (the rod is inserted and glued into the drum.) The drill has a maximum torque of 15 Nm. Will the rod break like in the vise, or is it a totally different situation?

I draw a picture to help. The Ai couldn't give me a definite answer and I am trying to wrap my mind around this. Are the two totally different situations or basically the exact same situation?

I do not know if it would break or not, but f it would, then I am confused, because I didn't expect metal axles to be so flimsy. Drill bits have very thin shafts but do not break from high torque drills.

Sex is species dependant. Some species have no sex, some can alternate between sexual reproduction and asexual reproduction, or switch sexes. Additionally, other forms of exchange of genetic code between members of a species that are not akin to sex exist. Further, we could well imagine a species that could evolve 3 or more sexes, aliens or future humans that reproduce solely through synthetic means (some livestock must already reproduce via synthetic means due changes in their physiology that preclude sex) and blend genetic code from many individuals, etc.

Following Aristotle, we should take the healthy member of the species as the norm. Humans have two sexes, genetic and developmental disorders that blur these lines not withstanding.

Gender isn't sex, hence two different words for them (in English anyhow). Ancient Greek complaints about men not acting like men don't make sense if gender is sex. How can males not act like all/most males act? Male behavior is what males actually do. Men's behavior, re: gender, is different, a prescribed ideal.

Also, quite a few languages assign gender to all sorts of things that lack biological sex. Tables and chairs have gender. Colors have gender associations, which obviously aren't rooted between any sort of antipathy between Y chromosomes and pink or violet wavelengths of light.

Only sex matters for most animals, and of course many species, for most of life's history, lacked any sex.

Gender is context dependant. It's clearly multidimensional and there are "infinite genders," simply in the trueism that there are infinitely many points in any n dimensional object due to denseness.

Gender is important for understanding human biology because it affects human mating behaviors and behaviors in general. But gender isn't sex.

Gender is an emergent phenomena. That doesn't somehow make it "soft." It exists in the same information theoretic frameworks that "genetic code" exists in.

Abstractions can be real and essential to describing reality at a basic level. Is time (moreover Minkoski proper time) not a real feature of reality? Zeno claimed it wasn't because an arrow in flight is never moving at any particular instant, frozen in time, and denied the existence of motion. As Aristotle pointed out, and Russell missed because he thought he was so far beyond Aristotle with set theory and a bad understanding of Cantor, is that this is a fallacy of composition. Time emerges as a dimension across which change occurs. No change, no time.

There is no atom of time except inasmuch as physics may show us that no changes occur in less than n amount of time, where the standard is an arbitrary repeating pattern that can be transformed into a continuum via calculation, but this finite quantization is an open question.

Abstractions are plenty real. Polka dot patterns don't not exist because no one circle makes polka dots. If that was the case then a genetic code couldn't exist because no codon makes a code. Gender affects human behavior and so is essential to human biology, it is that simple.

What people miss is the ability to keep and use the abstraction and not be drawn into social advocacy by fringe, but noisey political minorities.

>>15099606
Here is an information theoretic example. Imagine a binary code composed of x and y as the only characters. Since information is substrate dependant, and any good encoding as redundancy, we can read our code even if x and y are written by hand and no two x or y characters are exactly alike. There remain just two characters in the language despite variation.

Now suppose the transcription process for our code is sometimes subject to noise and this results in characters that are neither clearly x or y, but rather indiscernible as clearly x or y or make something looking for like a z.

This does not negate the binary language. What it will do is cause issues with parsing meaning and if the code contains instructions for its own replication then these errors may preclude replication.

Same thing with sex in humans. Functionally, you still need the xx/xy pairing for any replication.

For now anyhow. We may eventually reach a point where reproduction is possible between xx/xx pairs and xx/xy pairs, or other combinations not consistent with the norm. I don't foresee that being possible anytime soon though.

Suppose extra sexual chromosomes were far more common than they currently are and suppose that they did not interfere meaningfully with reproduction. In this case, you might end up with a population that was around 25% XX, 25% XXX, 25% XY, and 25% XYY.

However, XXX individuals present as female, with perhaps different mean values in some traits, but mostly overlapping distributions. The same is true for XYY individuals presenting as men.

Does this alternative version of humanity have two sexes or four?

I would argue two.

Meanwhile, if you had a species where three parents were required to reproduce, or reproduction could occur with either one or two partners of two distinct other sexes, then you would have more than two sexes.

Yes, although it is very rare. It's called de la Chapelle syndrome, and is caused by genes from the father's Y chromosome getting into the X chromosome of their sperm.

Many XX males have clear symptoms, less body hair, small testes, or even ambiguous genitalia, but not all. Masculinization of the brain still takes place because the signals are there.

Some have normal penises and they aren't even always sterile. The chromosomes just have instructions and if the signals for building a dick and testes are in place and nothing else hinders development then it can go along fine.

Anon, how is "what is sex overall," not relevant to "what is sex in x specific species?" The two have to be connected, particularly since species don't exist as static, Aristotelian essences, but are rather constantly changing.

The overarching concept is also relevant in that we can well imagine a time at some point in the next few centuries where technology has advanced to the point that people can reproduce without coitus and people of the same gender can produce genetically related offspring. Imagine this is the case, and further, imagine that because synthetic sexual reproduction grants other benefits by allowing for gene editing, the human species comes to reproduce largely (say > 90%) synthetically, through any combination of genetic material from either of the two previous sexes. In what sense would the human species have two sexes?

My point is that sex is best described in a manner akin to formalism in mathematics; a sex is what it does. The idea of an acultural, a technological human being makes no sense, humans have always had culture and technology, and the species' biological traits must be examined in that context.

As for Planck time, you're missing the point. The point is not that there is clear evidence that space-time is continuous or discrete, although arguably the balance of evidence is on the side of it being continuous to date. The point is that thinking the existence of Planck Time somehow demonstrates that time is discrete is to fundementally misunderstand Planck's constants. We could derive plenty of other constants, and indeed that's exactly what we have done with the metric system. Planck time just says "you cannot directly measure the timing of an event with a precision greater than the Planck time." But you can have light waves with a frequency shorter than one Planck length (this is entailed by general relativity) and there is no reason decoherence cannot occur in less than Planck time.

You're not even responding to the same person. And you didn't respond to any of the points raised previously.

As for sex being defined by the production of sperm and eggs, this is simply not how sex is defined in biology. And for good reason, since plants have sex, but produce neither sperm nor eggs, and yet the distinction of male and female is still useful there.

However, there are plenty of species where the gametes are isogamous, with no clear male or female, despite there being sexual reproduction. And yet since matches from distinct mating types are required, sex still exists, just non-male/female sex.

Sex is not defined completely by anisogamy, your point. When people talk about sex, particularly in animals, they are also referring to sexual dimorphism and sexual characteristics. For example, with XX males, few people would say, "there is a certain proportion of females born with penises and gonads." They would say there is a genetic disorder that results in the expression of a male phenotype.

If sex is sperm and eggs than a not insignificant proportion of many animals are born sexless despite having male or female genitalia and other traits, which doesn't make sense.

Or more to the point, there is a reason sex and anisogamy are not the same word.

There are some shitty dirt man ways of making decent clean rooms. (I've swapped HDD discs with an aquarium and a match.)
I understand the air particle requirements for silicon are magnitudes more restrictive than that, but that was just one shitty thing. If you start with stuff like that as a baseline and add on, I could see possibilities adding up.

Maybe you just create a multi-airlocking system, via boiled water, fire, and glass.
With just fire and glass you can start creating vacuum chambers. Make better and better vacuums, then you just start off with a shitty clean room via the fire method, and have a series of vacuum extractions. (You'd need to multi-phase this process 100%, you're basically just building a modern clean room, but instead of vacuum pumps, ionization pumps, static control, etc... You just pile on vacuum pumps and cage each step of the process. You're not trying to make TSMC, you don't really need a whole clean "room" You just need a clean vessel. Like a single enclosed box, probably made of glass, that you just continuously vacuum pump over and over via a steam system on the backend.

A multi-phase clean room that utilized those things could be a reality if they were really willing to do exactly what you told them.

Apologies for not piecing the ideas together in this post well, I have not slept in 40 hours+

Surely you can get a general grasp of what I'm getting at though. This is an engineering problem, and can be broken down and solved in smaller simple steps, piece by piece, until you approach workable conditions.
Some modern facilities use "clean boats" where the parts that need to be maintained in a clean room are actually just put into large boxes (boats) that are maintained as "clean" and then those boats are moved around the factory/warehouse and the parts within only move to other clean boats/boxes, via what equates to airlock docking.

Allows the larger warehouse/factory area to be more lax PPM requirements.

>>CS data structures
>Is this a meme class or should I take it seriously?
It will prep you for the BS interview questions, for which the answer is hash table if they want a O(1) solution, or asking you to implement some kinda tree.

Actual applied data structures, you're trying to minimize either memory, CPU, or worst case performance, usually CPU/speed. In practice you have to know how much RAM you have, how fast your RAM is, and your CPU cache and locality characteristics, and that's the shit they don't teach, cases where bubble sort IS faster.

posts.com: Do you want to make meme CRUD apps? Then it's not really important as you can use libraries more knowledgeable people have written and the user's machine is likely to shoulder most of the burden of poor performing code.
